text:
I'd be wary of it since that wasn't actually a planned end point for the clinical trial. We also don't know anything about durability of response (either with one dose it two). There are also unknowns regarding transmissibility, eg someone with both doses may be unable to transmit, while people with one dose can still be infected and transmit, even if they're protected (it's also possible people with two doses can still transmit, but...)

Given our current state of knowledge, I think we're better off giving full doses. We'll get observational studies going forward, since there will be people that only get one dose by accident, so thinking might change, but for now, I think getting fewer people (almost) fully protected is better than getting more people partly protected

text: I have a specific situation in mind. I don’t know what the health authorities in this country are planning to do, but the first shipment of the Pfizer vaccine is supposed to be 10,000 doses. I’m thinking they could give the first dose to 5,000 people, and save the remaining 5,000 doses for the second vaccination to those people. Alternatively they could vaccinate 10,000 people, and hope they get enough new supplies of the vaccine so they’re able to give them the second vaccine in a few weeks. But then they might not get new vaccine enough to give the second dose; it might get delayed. But if they do get enough new vaccines, vaccinating 10,000 at once saves time.

text: Well, it might depend on the logistics there, of actually giving the doses to people in various locations.  Start by giving out 1/6 of the doses each week, for the first 3 weeks.  Then, depending on whether you have received more vaccine or not, either just finish giving people their second dose, to have 5000 fully vaccinated (and those will likely be critical people, such as front-line healthcare workers).  If more supply has arrived, continue in the same fashion, streaming through the supply.

text: There are theoretical maximum efficiencies and then there's what's predicted by public health and sociology. The people that are going to be in line for the first round of vaccinations are the ones most likely to follow up. I think that strategy planning/hoping for the second dose to arrive on time makes some sense, but may backfire. The spacing in the study wasn't based on anything super concrete, so it's likely that waiting 6 weeks instead of 4 weeks would be fine, but we just don't know. The sad fact is that at the beginning, doubling the number vaccinated isn't going to make a big difference
